titles.title: Providing for the consideration of the Senate amendment to the bill (H.R. 5501) to authorize appropriations for fiscal years 2009 through 2013 to provide assistance to foreign countries to combat HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria, and for other purposes.

Providing for the consideration of the Senate amendment to the bill (H.R. 5501) to authorize appropriations for fiscal years 2009 through 2013 to provide assistance to foreign countries to combat HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria, and for other purposes.

action.text: The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 110-766, by Mr. Hastings (FL).

Upon the adoption of this resolution it shall be in order to take from the Speaker's table the bill H.R. 5501, with the Senate amendment thereto, and consider in the House a motion offered by the chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs or his designee, that the House concur in the Senate amendment. The motion shall be debatable for one hour, equally divided and controlled and the previous question shall be considered as ordered on the motion to its adoption without intervening motion.

calendar.text: Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 251.

action.text: DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 1362.

POSTPONED PROCEEDINGS - At the conclusion of debate on H.Res. 1362, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question, and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Lincoln Diaz-Balart (FL) demanded the yeas and nays, and further proceedings on ordering the previous question were postponed until later in the legislative day.
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 231 - 185 (Roll no. 526).

vote.text: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

bill.summary: Sets forth the rule for consideration of the Senate amendment to H.R. 5501(Tom Lantos and Henry J. Hyde United States Global Leadership Against HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria Reauthorization Act of 2008).
